Digilent WaveForms Controller¶

This module is made to control Digilent WaveForms compatible devices. It is developed with the Analog Discovery 2 but probably also works for the other devices.

It depends on Digilent’s DWF library wrapper (pip install dwf) which provides a pythonic way of interacting with the WaveForms dll. The DfwController class inherits from the Dwf class of the dwf module, meaning all functionality of Dwf is available. In addition the input and output channels are made available internally and basic methods are added to read and write analog values. The example code at the end shows both examples of using these basic methods and of interacting with the more complex inherited methods.

Unfortunately there’s no extended documentation for the dwf module, but original functions to interact with the dll are described in the WaveForms SDK Reference Manual. Using an autocompleting IDE it’s possible to explore the available methods and find the documentation of the corresponding functions in the WaveForms SDK Reference Manual.

In addition to the DfwController class this module contains functions to explore which devices are connected and to close connections.

class labphew.controller.digilent.waveforms.DfwController(device_number=0, config=0)[source]¶

Bases: dwf.Dwf

Controller for Digilent devices controlled through WaveForms software

__init__(device_number=0, config=0)[source]¶

Connect to device with optional configuration.

It connects to device with device_number as listed by the enumerate_devices() function of this module. Note that the default value of 0 will simply connect to the first device found. The possible configurations are also returned by enumerate_devices(). Note that enumerate devices is run at time of module import and stored in the variable devices. Note that the information returned by enumerate_devices() (or stored in the variable devices) can be diplayed in more readable form with the function print_device_list() of this module.

Parameters:
  • device_number (int) – the device number (default: 0)
  • config (int) – configuration number (default: 0)
preset_basic_analog(n=80, freq=10000, range=50.0, return_std=False)[source]¶

Apply settings for read_analog() and write_analog() Please note that there may be a significant overhead (delay) for reading which seems to be larger for lower frequencies and oddly seems to be larger for collecting a small number of points. The default values of averaging over 82 points at 10kHz results in <10ms per averaged datapoint.

Parameters:
  • n (int) – number of datapoints to collect and average (default 85)
  • freq (int or float or None) – analog in frequency (default 10000)
  • range (int or float or None) – the voltage range for the ADC (5.0 or 50.0) (default 50.0)
  • return_std (bool) – also returns the standard deviations (default False)
read_analog()[source]¶

Basic method to read voltage of analog in channels. See preset_basic_analog() to setup specifics for reading. Returns both channels. (Also returns standard deviations if self.basic_analog_return_std is True)

Returns:the analog values of both AI channels (and possibly the standard deviations)
Return type:float, float [,float, float] (or None’s in case of read timeout)
stop_analog_out(channel=-1)[source]¶

Basic method to stop analog output.

Parameters:channel (int) – analog out channel to stop (default is -1, meaning all channels)
wait_for_ai_acquisition(start_timestamp=None)[source]¶

Waits while ai status is busy. Uses the AI frequency and buffersize in combination with start_timestamp to calculate a read timeout. If no start_timestamp is supplied it uses time at moment of calling the method. It returns True if timeout occurred and None if acquisition finished regularly.

Parameters:start_timestamp (float or None) – the timestamp (as returned by time.time()) from which to calculate how long to wait
Returns:True for timeout, None when nothing happened
Return type:True or None
wait_for_stabilization()[source]¶

Waits for the output to stabilize. Note that this is calculated and approximated, not actively measured or verified.

Returns:the amount of time waited (s)
Return type:float
write_analog(volt, channel=-1, enable=True)[source]¶

Basic method to apply voltage to analog out channels. In the background it also approximates the timestamp when the output will be stabilize (based on the change in voltage applied). To wait for that timestamp, call wait_for_stabilization()

Parameters:
  • volt – voltage to apply (in Volt)
  • channel (int) – analog out channel to set (default is -1, meaning all channels)
  • delay (float) – delay (s) to wait after setting output to allow for stabilization
class labphew.controller.digilent.waveforms.SimulatedDfwController(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶

Bases: object

Rudimentary simulated version of DfwController for the purpose of developing without a connected device. Note that it is far from a complete simulation, it just mimics a few basic methods. You can add any simulation function to relate read_analog() to a value set with write_analog() via _analog_simulation_functions.

__init__(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶

Initialize self. See help(type(self)) for accurate signature.

close()[source]¶
preset_basic_analog(n=80, freq=10000, range=50.0, return_std=False)[source]¶

Simulated version of preset_basic_analog. Basically does nothing.

Parameters:
  • n (int) – number of datapoints to collect and average (default 85)
  • freq (int or float or None) – analog in frequency (default 10000)
  • range (int or float or None) – the voltage range for the ADC (5.0 or 50.0) (default 50.0)
  • return_std (bool) – also returns the standard deviations (default False)
read_analog()[source]¶

Simulated version of read_analog(). Applies functions specified in self._analog_simulation_functions (optionally to the values set by write_analog() ).

wait_for_ai_acquisition(start_timestamp=None)[source]¶

Simulated version of wait_for_ai_acquisition().

Parameters:start_timestamp (float or None) – is ignored in simulated version
wait_for_stabilization()[source]¶

Simulated version of wait_for_stabilization(). Waits for 0.1s.

Simulated version of write_analog().

Parameters:

  • channel –

labphew.controller.digilent.waveforms.close_all()[source]¶

Close all Digilent “WaveForms” devices

labphew.controller.digilent.waveforms.enumerate_devices()[source]¶

List connected devices and their possible configurations. Note: Use print_device_list() to easily display the result in readable form.

Returns:list of dictionaries containing information about the devices found
Return type:list
labphew.controller.digilent.waveforms.print_device_list(devices_list=None)[source]¶

Prints the information in the list generated by enumerate_devices() in a readable form. If no argument is given it prints the list stored at time of importing the module.

Parameters:devices (list) – the list generated by enumerate_devices() (or None (default) to print the list stored at import)
